summary: An interview with Ted Landsmark discussing critical views and hopeful outlooks on the architecture profession, emphasizing the need for a shift towards social and environmental responsibility.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying the text "an interview with Ted Landmark" in white letters, setting the stage for the interview. The scene then transitions to a man, Ted Landmark, dressed in a dark suit, light blue shirt, and patterned tie, speaking in an indoor setting with a blurred background. The text "arbuckle industries" appears in the bottom right corner, indicating the company associated with the interview. Throughout the video, Ted Landmark continues to speak, with slight variations in his facial expressions and head movements, suggesting an engaging conversation. The background remains consistent, featuring a softly lit room with indistinct objects, maintaining a professional atmosphere. The video maintains a steady focus on Ted Landmark, emphasizing his role as the interviewee and the context of the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with quiet, gentle piano music that evokes a contemplative mood. A male speaker then begins to discuss architecture, stating it has become "a commodity" produced by "highly skilled and talented artists" instead of serving a broader public need. He critiques the "rise of the starchitects," accusing them of prioritizing large-scale sculptures without fully considering how people will use, perceive, or safely enjoy those places. The piano music resumes quietly as the clip ends.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a suit and tie is seen speaking in an office environment. The background features maps and posters on the walls, including one that reads "CRUCIAL WELLS" with a red ribbon symbol, indicating a possible connection to health or awareness campaigns. The office has a modern look with visible lighting fixtures and a door leading to another room. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as suggested by his facial expressions and gestures. The text "arbuckleindustries" is visible in the lower right corner, likely indicating the company or organization associated with the video. The overall atmosphere is professional and informative, with the man's attire and the office setting reinforcing this impression.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker arguing that much of what has been celebrated in architecture has been a kind of "self-indulgence" on the part of architects who have "often been dismissive" of their clients and their clients' real needs. The speaker then claims that these architects have looked at buildings that have leaked or have not worked effectively, or have not provided the kind of environmental security that they ought to have provided.  He finishes by saying, "we've made stars of those individuals, I think to the detriment of the public at large."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and glasses, dressed in a suit and tie, speaking in an indoor setting. The background is blurred, but it appears to be a well-lit room with large windows. Throughout the video, the man's facial expressions and mouth movements suggest he is engaged in a conversation or delivering a speech. The text "arbuckle industries" is visible in the bottom right corner of the frames, indicating the name of the company or organization associated with the video. The man's attire and the professional setting imply a formal or business-related context. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man, with no significant changes in the environment or his appearance.
events_list.audio_caption: A man speaks in a calm, reflective tone, commenting positively on a shift in architecture schools, noting how students are "asking for a more socially conscious and a more environmentally conscious kind of architecture," one that "really serves human needs."

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen displaying the text "What are the demographics of the architectural profession?" in white font. The scene then transitions to a man wearing glasses and a suit, speaking in an indoor setting with a blurred background. The text "arbuckle industries" appears in the bottom right corner of the screen. The man continues to speak, and the camera zooms out to reveal more of the room, which is decorated with maps and posters on the walls. The video then cuts to a close-up of the man's face, focusing on his expressions as he speaks. Throughout the video, the man maintains a professional demeanor, and the background remains consistent, featuring a well-lit room with a modern aesthetic. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with the camera capturing his upper body and the surrounding environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker, reflecting on architecture as a "small and privileged profession." He notes the limited number of licensed architects in the United States and the lack of diversity within the field, stating "fewer than a quarter of all of the licensed architects... are women", and that "fewer than 6% are people of color". He continues in a similar thoughtful tone to discuss how this demographic tends to reward itself for its work.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a suit and tie, seated in an office environment. He appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his facial expressions and gestures. The office is decorated with various maps and posters on the walls, including one that reads "CRUCIAL WELLS" with a red ribbon symbol, suggesting a focus on health or awareness campaigns. The room is well-lit, with natural light coming from a window in the background, and there is a visible bookshelf filled with books. The text "arbuckle industries" is displayed in the lower right corner of the frame, likely indicating the name of the company or organization associated with the video. Throughout the video, the man's expressions and gestures change subtly, indicating the flow of his speech or presentation. The overall atmosphere is professional and informative, with the man appearing to be the central figure in the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker with a somewhat critical tone, observing that despite "about 115 architecture schools in the United States," awards tend to favor graduates from a "small handful, maybe a half a dozen," primarily from the Northeast and Northwest coast. He continues, saying that magazines celebrating architects focus on a limited group, often not even American, who do "particular narrow kind of work for wealthy clients." The speaker appears slightly irritated.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen displaying white text that reads, "How has the privileged nature of architects effected the kind of work that has been built?" (How has the privileged nature of architects affected the kind of work that has been built?). The scene then transitions to a man in a suit and tie, seated in an office environment. The office is decorated with various maps and posters on the walls, and a bulletin board with a red ribbon symbol is visible in the background. The man appears to be speaking, as indicated by his mouth movements and the presence of a microphone clipped to his suit. The text "arbuckle industries" is displayed in the bottom right corner of the screen. The video continues with the man speaking, and the camera zooms in for a close-up shot, focusing on his face and upper body. The background remains consistent, with the office setting and decorations still visible. The video maintains a professional and informative atmosphere throughout, with the man's attire and the office environment suggesting a formal discussion or presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing wealth in the United States, commenting that wealth has "gone into supporting a kind of design" emphasizing style over substance. He critiques designs created in recent years, noting "they may look great" but may not fit or function optimally. The clip ends with another man speaking.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a suit and tie, wearing glasses, speaking in an office environment. The background includes maps and posters on the wall, with a bulletin board displaying various notices and a sign that reads "CERICAL WELLS." The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his facial expressions and gestures. The text "arbuckle industries" is visible in the bottom right corner of the frames, suggesting a corporate or business context. The setting is professional, with a focus on the man and the informative elements in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing societal issues related to design, such as cars, electrical instruments, cities, and buildings, alluding to excessive energy consumption and a focus on individual desires over societal needs. His tone is reflective and critical, indicating a concern for the consequences of current design practices. There are no background sounds or music in the audio.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and patterned tie, speaking directly to the camera. He has a beard and wears glasses, and his facial expressions suggest he is engaged in a conversation or delivering a speech. The background is blurred, but it appears to be an indoor setting with a map visible on the wall behind him. The text "arbuckle industries" is displayed in the lower right corner of the frame, indicating the name of the company or organization associated with the video. Throughout the video, the man's expressions and mouth movements change as he speaks, and the camera remains focused on him, capturing his upper body and face. The lighting is bright and even, highlighting the man's features and the details of his attire. The overall atmosphere of the video is professional and formal, with the man appearing confident and composed as he addresses the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing a "point of crisis" and how "things designed over the last 15, 20 years have failed us". He mentions that these things may be "using too much energy" or "breaking down excessively", spoken with a concerned tone. He concludes that they "are not meeting the kinds of needs we would have anticipated".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a suit and tie is seen speaking in an office environment. The background features maps and posters on the walls, with a visible sign that reads "ar buckle industries." The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his facial expressions and gestures. The office setting is well-lit, with a modern and professional atmosphere. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and the office environment throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a challenge in design: to recalibrate design thinking and incorporate a new value set, one that emphasizes real human needs over style. The speaker speaks in a serious and thoughtful tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen displaying the text "What is the new generation of architecture students like?" in white font. The scene then transitions to an indoor setting where a man, dressed in a dark suit, light blue shirt, and patterned tie, is seated in front of a wall adorned with maps and posters. The room features a modern design with exposed ceiling pipes and track lighting. To the right, a bulletin board displays various notices, including one that reads "25 Years of AIDS Awareness" and another titled "Criminal Wills." The man appears to be speaking, as indicated by his mouth movements and the presence of a microphone clipped to his suit. The video maintains this setting and focus on the man throughout, with no significant changes in the environment or his position. The text "arbuckle industries" is visible in the bottom right corner of the screen, suggesting a possible affiliation or sponsorship. The overall atmosphere is professional and informative, with the man likely discussing topics related to architecture or education.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on the privilege of working in architectural and environmental education, particularly with current students. He notes the increasing focus on students' technical skills, enabling them to work faster and smarter with more information and diverse materials. The speaker expresses that this progress is "wonderful".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a suit and tie is seen speaking in an office environment. The background features maps and posters on the walls, including one that reads "25 Years of AIDS Research" and another with the text "arbutuck industries." The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his facial expressions and gestures. The office setting is well-lit, with visible bookshelves and a window in the background, creating a professional atmosphere. The man's attire and the office decor suggest a formal and business-oriented context.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker describing how students in recent years are "much more committed to social service" and "issues of service to those who have traditionally been underserved." The speaker speaks in a conversational and enthusiastic tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses, a suit, and a patterned tie is seen speaking in an office environment. The background features a wall adorned with maps and posters, including one that reads "25 Years of AIDS Research" and another with the text "CRUCIAL WELLS" and "arbutuck industries." The office has a modern look with exposed ceiling pipes and track lighting. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his hand gestures and facial expressions. The setting suggests a professional atmosphere, possibly related to research or industry, with the presence of informational materials and a bulletin board filled with various notices and documents.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of one male speaker in a conversational tone. He discusses the architectural style of Frank Gehry and the desire of other architects to emulate it by "creat[ing] great sculptures in the landscape," noting the irrelevance of whether these sculptures were functional. He states that the era of using "aerospace engineering to come up with forms that hadn't been built before" is over.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a suit and tie, wearing glasses, speaking in an office setting. The background includes maps and posters on the wall, with a visible sign that reads "ar buckle industries." The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The office environment is professional, with a bulletin board and a window visible in the background. The video concludes with a transition to a black screen displaying the "ar buckle industries" logo, which consists of a stylized infinity symbol with colorful dots inside it. The logo is accompanied by the company name in lowercase letters, reinforcing the branding of the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing how students are considering work in specific areas, focusing on the needs of people in refugee camps and individuals worldwide. The speaker emphasizes the need for affordable and sustainable living. He notes that students push design schools to rethink faculty perspectives on the environment and prioritize long-term sustainability for clients. Finally, the sound of a sewing machine starts.
